fields.headline: Never the twine
fields.bodyText: It's typical of the white rose county to think they may have cornered the market in binder twine (Letters, 30 July). But it's only on this side of the Pennines that it really comes into its own (having been employed ingeniously to join the scaffolding used in the building of Blackpool Tower). Parts of the country's first motorway (the Preston bypass) were surfaced with reconstituted twine, while it's not unknown for engine drivers at Carnforth to strengthen their couplings with it in preparation for the run up to Shap. When Kipling was talking of east and west it was, of course, a coded reference to the wars of the roses, hence his coining the expression "never the twine shall meet". Chris Haughton Preesall, Lancashire • Full Norfolk toolkit: 3-in-One Oil to get it going, binder twine to keep it stopped. Malcolm Redfellow London • Your article (Pick up a Penguin: publisher celebrates 75th anniversary, 31 July) does not mention that Penguin books was the brainchild of Allen Lane and his colleague at Bodley Head, Krishna Menon. The partnership did not last long. Menon was a pro-independence activist living in Britain; he held many government posts after India became independent. Marika Sherwood Institute of Commonwealth Studies • The bees and butterflies on my knapweed and thistles are getting fewer at this time of year (Plantwatch, 28 July). Instead the seed heads are visited by flocks of goldfinches. Another good reason for growing such plants in the garden and not consigning them to the countryside. Janet Gyford Witham, Essex • Working at a bookstore in London's Piccadilly many years ago, I was asked by a very aristocratic-looking lady if we had any books about "Skites" (Letters, 31 July). After several failed attempts to decipher what she wanted, in desperation she said: "You know, Skites … Skites and Brinies … founded by Baden-Powell!" Steve Liversedge Jaywick, Essex • Over Auckland airport's PA I heard the Kiwi operative requesting a stray passenger to "proceed to the chicken zone". Peter Gill Shrewsbury, Shropshire
